etymologies: late 15th century; earliest use found in Chartier's Traité de l'Esperance. Apparently a variant of merlin, although used in the sense of merlette

definitions: A representation of a bird with either no feet or neither feet nor beak. Compare "martlet", merlette.

etymologies: 1970s; earliest use found in Singapore 1973. From mer- + lion

definitions: A mythical creature with the head and trunk of a lion and the tail of a fish, regarded as the protector of Singapore.

notes.text: The merlion is represented on a celebrated monument installed in Merlion Park, Singapore, on 15 Sept. 1972.
